dataset.title: The effects of time of day, gender, and age on time budgets in African Elephants in Kruger National Park

individualName.surName: Billy Boysen, Wren Larson, Jodie Reed

abstract.para: The African elephant, Loxodonta africana, is a species of great importance in Kruger National Park because of the extensive impact it has on ecological processes. In this study, we focused on the effects of time of day, gender and age on time budgets in elephants. We sought to determine whether there were any activities that were performed more frequently at different times of the day or by elephants of a certain age or gender. Using focal observation, we determined the proportion of total time spent performing various activities. We found that the time budgets did not vary statistically with gender or age, but that there were significant differences in time spent standing still between the morning and afternoon (p=0.0143). More time was spent eating in the afternoon than the morning (p=0.002183), but overall time spent eating was less than previous studies have found. Despite the fact that elephant populations in Kruger are growing, the destruction of trees was not observed in any of our focal studies, indicating elephants in our study did not appear to impact the ecosystem as much as reported in previous literature.

section.para: The study focused on the African Elephant, Loxodonta africana, the largest of all
land mammals. Adult males can weigh over 6000 kg, with 200 kg contributing to the
ivory tusks. When protected, an elephant can live to be over 70 years, constrained only by
the irreplaceable six molar pairs that wear down over time (Frandsen 1998). For this
behavioral study, we actively searched for elephants twice a day in Open Air Game
Viewing Vehicles from September 21-24, 2006. Weather conditions were dry and hot,
with temperatures around 30° C. Searching was held in the morning, 7:00 AM-12:00
PM, and afternoon, 12:00 PM-6:00 PM. All searching and observations were conducted
along the Shingwedzi River within 30 km of the Shingwedzi Research Camp in Kruger
National Park, South Africa (S 23.05682; E 031.34634). The majority of elephants were
studied along the riverbank, with observation occurring from the opposite bank. Some
individuals were encountered along the road and were observed there.
When an elephant was observed, a GPS locator was used to pinpoint the location
of the animal. The time of observation was noted and the elephant was classified in
terms of age and gender. Three distinct age classes were used to categorize elephants:
infant, juvenile, and adult. An infant was defined as any small elephant that had not yet
developed tusks. A juvenile was any tusked individual in the herd not yet fully grown,
generally 75% or less of the size of the largest animals (adults). Ambiguity in the sexes
prevented the identification of genders in the infants and juveniles. As a result, only the
adult elephants were classified as male or female.
After gender and age classification, activity budgets were determined through
observation in focal studies (Altmann 1974). During the ten-minute focal observation, the
activity of one elephant was carefully described and timed. One person observed the
elephant through binoculars while a second recorded all of the reported observation.
These descriptions were used to later classify the behavior into seven categories: eating,
standing, drinking, traveling (walking or running), vigilance (looking around, head
shaking, ears out), playing (trunk wrestling, shoving, butting, splashing, etc.), and other
(mating, scratching, rolling around in the mud, nursing) (Estes 1999). Data were
collected from 64 elephants. Because the elephants were observed from a distance, we
assumed that our presence did not have an effect on their behavior.
We calculated our statistics using Statistica 7.0 (StatSoft, Inc. © 1984-2004). The
data were tested for normality using the Lilliefors test and found to be non-normally
distributed; therefore we used nonparametric statistical tests in the analysis of our data.
To analyze the effect of gender and age on time budgets we used a Kruskal-Wallis oneway
ANOVA. If significant differences were detected, a Mann-Whitney U test was
performed between adult males and adult females. If no significant differences were
detected, these two groups were combined and reclassified as adults. The Kruskal-Wallis
test was then performed on the three age groups and if significant differences were
detected, this was followed by Mann-Whitney U tests of pairs of age groups per activity,
along with a Bonforoni correction. The variability in the activity budgets due to the
effect of time of day was analyzed using Mann-Whitney U tests.
